title: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
source: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
text:
Important information for those subject to immigration control
From July 1, 2021, if you are getting married or entering into a civil partnership in England and Wales, you will need to give notice at a register office in the district where either you or your partner live.
If either of you are not British or Irish citizens, or do not have settled or pre-settled status in the UK, you may need to provide additional documentation.
Abuse of immigration laws
We are working with the UK Border Agency to identify marriages and civil partnerships which seek to abuse UK immigration laws.
Anybody found to be arranging, facilitating or entering into a marriage or civil partnership solely to gain permission to stay in the UK risks arrest or prosecution.
Foreign nationals may also face deportation and be barred from re-entering the UK for up to 14 years.

title: Register a birth
summary: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
intro: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
text:
Overview
It is a legal requirement to register a birth within 42 days of your baby being born.
You will need a birth certificate when applying for any benefits related to the birth of a new born.
You must have an appointment to register a birth at the Knowsley Register Office.
Where to register a birth
The birth must be registered at the Register Office for the district where the birth occurred.
If you are not able to travel to Knowsley Register Office you can contact your local register office to enquire about making a birth declaration.
They will gather the information needed to register a birth (as detailed above) and ask you to sign a declaration form. They will send this to us, where the birth will be registered.

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
Registering a death
Deaths are registered at the local register office for the area where the death took place.
Before a death can be registered, the Knowsley Register Office must receive documents from a medical examiner or the coroner's office.
Where a cause of death is known, a GP or hospital doctor should inform the medical examiner—a senior doctor who provides independent scrutiny of the cause of death. When the medical examiner has reviewed the cause, they will approve the documents to be sent to the Register Office. The medical examiner will then contact the family to discuss the cause of death and any concerns you may have.
If the death has been reported to the coroner, they will advise when it can be registered.
Once the Register Office receives the relevant documents, we will contact the next of kin to arrange an appointment to register the death.

title: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
source: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
text:
What documentation you will need
To prove your nationality, age, and name
Bring your current passport.
If you are British and do not have a current passport, bring your full British birth certificate and a proof of name document, such as a UK driving licence with a photo. If your name has changed, you will need to provide a linking document. For example, change of name deed.
If you are bringing your full British birth certificate and you were born in the UK after January 1 1983, you will also need to provide evidence of the nationality of your parents.
To prove your residence
Bring one of the following
A current UK driving licence
A bank or building society statement dated within 1 month of your appointment
Your council tax bill dated within the last 12 months
A utility bill dated within the last 3 months, for services received at the property (but not a mobile phone bill)
If you have EU settled or pre-settled status
Bring a share code dated within 30 days of your appointment. You can get a share code at
gov.uk
.

links.context: Bring a share code dated within 30 days of your appointment. You can get a share code atgov.uk.

title: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
source: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
text:
If you have been married or have entered into a civil partnership before
If either of you has been divorced from a marriage or has obtained dissolution from a civil partnership in England or Wales, we will need to see the original court stamped decree absolute/final order/dissolution. This must be a paper copy.
Please note that, if the name appearing on this document differs from the name on the other documentation being provided for notice of marriage, a linking document must be provided (e.g. previous marriage certificate).
If you have been divorced in England or Wales
You will need to provide the original court-stamped decree absolute or dissolution. This must be a paper copy. If the name on this document is different from the name on your other documentation, you will also need to provide a linking document, such as a previous marriage certificate.
If you have been divorced abroad
If the divorce/dissolution took place in a foreign country we will need to see the original documents, plus an official English translation if necessary.  In order for the documentation to be checked an additional charge will be incurred.  Please contact us on 0151 443 2900 and select option 3 for further information.
If you are widowed
If either of you is a widow, widower or surviving civil partner we will need to see a certified copy of your partner's death certificate and in some cases your marriage/civil partnership certificate.
If you have already married each other abroad
You will only need to marry again in the UK if you are not sure whether your foreign marriage is legal.
It is important you provide the correct documents at your appointment so we can complete your notice of marriage.
Please contact us on 0151 443 2900 for further guidance or visit
www.gov.uk
.

links.context: Please contact us on 0151 443 2900 for further guidance or visitwww.gov.uk.

title: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
source: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
text:
What happens after a notice of marriage or civil partnership
Your notice will be displayed on the public notice board at the register office for 28 days. Then, the marriage district will issue a marriage or civil partnership schedule. The schedule is valid for 12 months from the date you gave notice, and only for the venue you have specified.

title: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
source: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
text:
Special licence
If someone or their partner has a terminal illness it is possible to get a licence to marry or form a civil partnership very quickly without having to give the usual statutory notices.
You will need to speak to a Registrar who can provide further information.
Please contact the Knowsley Register Office.

title: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
source: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
text:
Church of England
If you are getting married in the Church of England, please contact the Vicar of the church for advice on legal requirements for marriages and fees.

title: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
source: Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
text:
Fees
The fee for each notice is £42 and is payable at the time of giving the notice of marriage or civil partnership.
For notices that require referral to the Home Office, the fee for each notice is £57.
We accept payment by credit/debit card.

title: Register a birth
summary: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
intro: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
text:
Who can register a birth
If you are married or in a civil partnership, either parent can register the birth.
If you are not married or in a civil partnership, the father’s details can only be entered if both parents are present at the registration appointment.
However, in certain circumstances the father's details can be entered into the register without him being present.
If the birth is to be registered with two female parents please telephone 0151 443 2900 for further advice.
Please contact the office on 0151 443 2900 for further advice and guidance.

title: Register a birth
summary: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
intro: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
text:
What information is needed
When and where the birth occurred. In the case of multiple births, the time of birth for each child.
The full name of the child and correct spelling
Full names of the parent(s) and correct spelling
Mother's maiden name (if applicable)
Address of parents
Occupation of parents
Dates of birth and places of birth of parents
If married, date of marriage
What documents you will need
The baby’s red book
Other documents
It would be helpful to bring along supporting documentation to ensure information recorded in the register is accurate (for example passport, driving licence, utility bill, birth and marriage certificates).
Don’t worry if any of these documents are not available as the registrar can still complete the birth registration.

title: Register a birth
summary: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
intro: Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.
text:
What surname will the baby have
Choosing your child's surname
Your child can take the surname of either parent, or both. Even if you are not married and the father doesn't attend the birth registration, you can still give your child the father's surname.
Changing your child's surname
Once your child's name and surname have been registered, it can only be changed in the following circumstances:
You apply to re-register the birth to have the father's details included, if they were not included in the first entry.
You get married after registering the birth. In this case, you should re-register the birth, even if you gave your child their father's surname at the original registration.
To re-register a birth, you will need to contact the register office where the birth was originally registered.

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
Who can register a death
A relative or partner of the deceased
A personal representative of the deceased (a solicitor, family friend, funeral director, etc., appointed by the deceased themselves or by the family)
A person present at the death
The person making the funeral arrangements
The occupier of the building where the death occurred (for example, a care home manager)

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
What information you will need when registering a death
You will need to provide the registrar with the following information about the deceased.
Full name, surname, and any previous names (such as maiden name if married)
Date and place of death
Date and place of birth
Occupation and marital status (married or civil partner)
Name, occupation, and date of birth of spouse or civil partner (if applicable)
Home address
Whether the deceased was receiving a pension or public fund allowance

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
What documentation you will need
It would be helpful to bring the following documents to ensure that the information recorded in the register is accurate. However, don't worry if you don't have all of these documents, as the registrar can still complete the registration.
Documents about the deceased
Passport
Driving licence
Utility bill
Birth and marriage/civil partnership certificates
NHS medical card
Deed poll (if the deceased had changed their name)
Documents about you
Passport
Driving licence
Proof of address (such as a utility bill or council tax statement)

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
What happens next
At the registration appointment, we will give you a document that allows the burial or cremation to take place, unless the coroner has already done so.
Alternatively, with your consent, we can scan this document to the crematorium or burial authority.

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
Tell Us Once
After you have registered the death, the Registrar will provide you with a unique Tell Us Once reference number, which will enable you to
access the service Online via GOV.UK
.
If you have been issued with a Coroners Fact of Death (Interim Death Certificate) you may still be able to use the service and the Registrar will advise you how to do so. Learn more about Tell Us Once in the video below.
British Sign Language version

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
How to use the Tell Us Once service
To use the Tell Us Once service, you will need a unique Tell Us Once reference number, which you will receive from the Registrar after you have registered the death. You can then access the service online via
GOV.UK
.
If you have been issued with a Coroner's Fact of Death (Interim Death Certificate), you may still be able to use the service. The Registrar will advise you on how to do this.
Before using Tell Us Once, it will be helpful to have the following information about the deceased
Date of birth
Address
National Insurance number
Driving licence number (if applicable)
Vehicle registration number (if applicable)
Passport number (if applicable)
You will also need the following information
Details of any benefits or entitlements the deceased was receiving, such as State Pension or Universal Credit
Details of any local council services the deceased was receiving, such as Adult Social Services or a Blue Badge
The name and address of the deceased's next of kin
The name and address of any surviving spouse or civil partner (if applicable)
The name, address, and contact details of the person or company dealing with the deceased's estate (property, belongings, and money), known as their 'executor' or 'administrator' (if applicable)
Details of any public sector or armed forces pension schemes the deceased was getting or paying into (if applicable)
Once you have all of this information, you can visit the
GOV.UK website
to start the Tell Us Once process.

links.context: To use the Tell Us Once service, you will need a unique Tell Us Once reference number, which you will receive from the Registrar after you have registered the death. You can then access the service online viaGOV.UK.
Once you have all of this information, you can visit theGOV.UK websiteto start the Tell Us Once process.

title: Registering a death
summary: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
intro: Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
text:
Other information
Please note
Before you can use Tell Us Once, you must get permission from the next of kin, the executor, the administrator, and anyone who was claiming benefits or entitlements jointly with the deceased.
You do not need to follow up with any of the services after you have used Tell Us Once, unless you do not receive a confirmation from the relevant department within a reasonable period of time (usually one month).
Once the various agencies informed by Tell Us Once have received notification of the death, they will make any further contact if necessary with the bereaved family.
Tell Us Once is not a claim to benefit, so please contact GOV.UK or the relevant department for advice.
Tell Us Once does not notify any commercial organisations of the death. Please inform the landlord of the deceased person.
Tell Us Once cannot arrange for redirection of post.
Privacy notice
Knowsley Council uses the information you provide for the 'Tell Us Once' service to enable us to notify a range of council and central government services on your behalf.
The council uses a secure network to share your information and we will only pass on the minimum amount of information that is necessary.
If you have any comments, queries or concerns about Data Protection, please visit the
data protection page
.

links.context: Knowsley Council uses the information you provide for the 'Tell Us Once' service to enable us to notify a range of council and central government services on your behalf.The council uses a secure network to share your information and we will only pass on the minimum amount of information that is necessary.If you have any comments, queries or concerns about Data Protection, please visit thedata protection page.

title: Book a citizenship ceremony
summary: If you have been granted British citizenship, you must attend a citizenship ceremony within three months of approval being granted, find out more here.
intro: If you have been granted British citizenship, you must attend a citizenship ceremony within three months of approval being granted, find out more here.
text:
About citizenship ceremonies
If you have been granted British citizenship, you must attend a citizenship ceremony within three months of approval being granted. This is a formal occasion to welcome you into your new community and to celebrate your new status as a British citizen.
During the ceremony, you will take an oath to His Majesty the King and a pledge of loyalty to the UK. You will also receive your certificate of British citizenship.
The ceremony is a special opportunity to mark your new beginning as a British citizen. It is also a chance to meet other new citizens and to learn more about your local community.
How to arrange a ceremony
Once you have received your letter of approval from the Home Office, please contact Knowsley Register Office to find out which citizenship ceremony you can attend.
What happens at a citizenship ceremony
A standard group citizenship ceremony will include the following:
Introduction and welcome
Address by a local dignitary
Swearing or affirming the oath and pledge
Official response
Presentation of the citizenship certificate
On the day of the ceremony you must bring your approval letter from the Home Office, the letter you receive from Knowsley Register Office and your photographic identification. Without these documents you may be refused admission to the ceremony.
Private citizenship ceremonies
Citizenship ceremonies are usually conducted in groups to highlight the community nature of citizenship. However, if you would like to have a more personal ceremony, Knowsley Registration Service can offer a private ceremony for a fee.
Fees and venues from April 2024 to March 2025
See the fees list

title: Book a naming ceremony
summary: A naming ceremony a non-religious celebration of a child's birth and naming. Find out more about booking your child's ceremony here.
intro: A naming ceremony a non-religious celebration of a child's birth and naming. Find out more about booking your child's ceremony here.
text:
About naming ceremonies
A naming ceremony is a non-religious ceremony to celebrate the birth and naming of a child or to welcome an adopted child or stepchild of any age into a new family. The ceremony has no legal status.
Knowsley Registration Service can help you create a meaningful and memorable ceremony that is tailored to your family's specific needs and preferences. We offer a variety of venues within the borough, including the Register Office, or you can choose to hold the ceremony at another approved premise.
Registrar attendance at approved premises in Knowsley
Knowsley Hall
The Village Hotel, Liverpool
Suites Hotels Knowsley
The Barn at Yew Tree Farm
Please contact us for further information. You will also need to contact your chosen venue to make arrangements for your ceremony.
Fees and venues from April 2024 to March 2025
Knowsley Registration Service offers a variety of rooms at the office to suit all tastes.
See the fees list
.

title: Marriage and civil partnership venues
summary: Looking for the perfect venue to host your civil marriage or partnership? Take a look at the venues we have to offer in Knowsley.
intro: Looking for the perfect venue to host your civil marriage or partnership? Take a look at the venues we have to offer in Knowsley.
text:
Under the Marriage Act of 1994, civil marriages and civil partnerships can take place in a variety of venues.
Knowsley Registration Office
The office offers a variety of rooms, from a small ceremony room to the unique garden gazebo.
Room
Guests
Statutory Room
Strictly 2 witnesses only
Small Ceremony Room
Up to 10 guests
Priestcote Room
Up to 50 guests
Garden Gazebo
Up to 50 guests
Knowsley approved venues
Knowsley Hall
The Village Hotel, Liverpool
Suites Hotels Knowsley
The Barn at Yew Tree Farm
View the fees here.
Other types of weddings
Church of England weddings
To arrange a Church of England wedding, please contact your local vicar.
Weddings at other religious buildings
If you are planning to marry in a different religious building, you should contact the person in charge of marriages at the building and give notice of marriage at your local register office. You can only be married in a church in a different district from where you both live if one or both parties usually worship in that building or there is no church of your religion in the district where you or the person you are marrying lives.
Weddings for people who are ill
If you are not able to attend a church or register office because of long term or serious illness, you can be married at home or in hospital. Please contact the Register Office on 0151 443 2900.  If you call out of office hours, please follow the instructions provided on the telephone message.
To give notice of your intention to marry or form a civil partnership
You must both be at least 18 years old.
You must both be free to marry or form a civil partnership.
You must both live in the same district as the register office where you are giving notice.
To give notice, you will need to book an appointment at your local register office. You can do this online or by phone. At your appointment, you will need to bring your identification documents and pay a fee.
Once you have given notice, your notice will be displayed on the public notice board at the register office for 28 days. After 28 days, you will be issued with a marriage or civil partnership schedule. This schedule is valid for 12 months from the date you gave notice.
On the day of your ceremony, you will need to bring your marriage or civil partnership schedule to the ceremony venue.

title: Order a copy certificate

Full birth certificate
£12.50
Short birth certificate (does not include details of the parents and may not be accepted by passport offices or other organisations)
£12.50
Marriage or civil partnership certificate
£12.50
Death certificate
£12.50
Your certificate will be posted out to you by second class mail within 15 working days.
Priority Copy Certificate Service
A Priority Service is available which means you will receive your copy certificate more quickly for a fee of £38.50.
This service is available up to 3pm from Monday to Friday.
The certificate will be posted out by first class mail.
Family history research
Please note that certificates for family history research will be issued as quickly as possible, but requests may take longer due to the extra search time required.

title: Registering a stillbirth
summary: Losing a baby is devastating, we understand that this is a very difficult time for you and your family. We will ensure that the process of registering the stillbirth is as easy as possible and you get the right information.
intro: Losing a baby is devastating, we understand that this is a very difficult time for you and your family. We will ensure that the process of registering the stillbirth is as easy as possible and you get the right information.
text:
A stillborn child is a child born after week 24 of pregnancy who did not show any sign of life after being born.
If your baby was born before week 24, we cannot register the stillbirth for you. However, you can still arrange a funeral for your baby.
Stillbirths should be registered within 12 months of your child being born.
A medical certificate will be issued by the hospital doctor or registered midwife, who will send it directly to Knowsley Register Office. Once received, you will be contacted by telephone to make an appointment to attend the office for the stillbirth registration.
If your baby was born outside of Knowsley, we can take the information from you but we cannot register the stillbirth.  We will send the information on to the register office in the district where your baby was born.  That office will then issue the documents you may need to arrange a funeral.
Who can register
If the parents were married or in a civil partnership at the time of conception or stillbirth, either parent can register alone.  If not, and you want the father’s details to be entered in the register, then both parents can attend to sign the register together.
How long the process takes
The registration process should take about half an hour to complete.
If either parent is unable to attend, please contact us.
Baby loss certificate
If your pregnancy ends before 24 weeks, we cannot register the stillbirth for you, however you can get a certificate in memory of your baby.

A Renewal of Vows Ceremony is a non-religious ceremony for couples who want to celebrate their love and commitment to each other. Knowsley Registration Service can personalise a ceremony to include events that have taken place during your married life, family, and friends.
You can hold your ceremony at one of the venues at the Register Office or at an approved premise within the borough.

title: Burials and cremations
summary: If you are organising a burial, or burial following a cremation, there are a number of options available to you. Find out more here.
intro: If you are organising a burial, or burial following a cremation, there are a number of options available to you. Find out more here.
text:
Your Funeral Director will be able to advise you on most matters including contacting relevant clergy, arranging a hearse and may be able to arrange the burial with us on your behalf.
Burials
Burials can be arranged at
Knowsley Cemetery and Prescot Cemetery.
All new burial graves can accommodate one, two, or three coffins and up to four cremated remains caskets. Costs vary depending on the size of the grave selected.
You can purchase the right of burial to a grave space for immediate use or reserve it in advance for a period of 99 years. At the end of this period, your family will have the option to renew these rights.
If a family member already owns the right of burial but is now deceased, you may apply to transfer ownership.
The Bereavement Services team can answer your individual questions and help you with your requirements.
A range of
memorials and headstones
are available. Cemetery staff can advise you and provide costs.
See burial costs here.
Burials following cremation
Special areas for the burial of ashes are located at
Fox's Bank Lane Cemetery and Prescot Cemetery
. Each plot is allocated with a 99-year right of burial and can accommodate up to six sets of ashes. Headstones can also be placed on the plots.
To help the environment, we ask that remains be buried in a biodegradable container. Your funeral director or the cemetery office staff can advise you on this.
Arranging a burial or scattering of ashes
To arrange a burial or burial following a cremation, please call Knowsley Bereavement Services. You can also arrange to scatter ashes in the
Garden of Remembrance at Fox's Bank Lane Cemetery.
Finding a relative's grave
Knowsley Bereavement Services keeps records of all burials, graves, and memorials in the borough's cemeteries.
If you are doing a genealogy study or need information from a large period of time, there may be a charge.
Contact
Address
Knowsley Bereavement Services Office
Knowsley Council Register Office
High Street Prescot
L34 3LH
E-mail
knowsley.bereavement.services@knowsley.gov.uk
Telephone
0151 443 5231

title: Memorials
summary: You may wish to arrange for a memorial headstone or plaque to be placed on the grave of a loved one or family member laid to rest in a Knowsley cemetery.
intro: You may wish to arrange for a memorial headstone or plaque to be placed on the grave of a loved one or family member laid to rest in a Knowsley cemetery.
text:
Memorial headstones
To install a memorial headstone, you must have permission from the council. You can get  this permission through an approved memorial stone mason, who can also advise you on sizes, wording, and construction.
The memorial stone mason will also contact the cemetery to make sure that the headstone meets size and health and safety standards.
Some headstones can be installed immediately following burial, but in other cases there may need to be a delay to allow the ground to settle.
Once positioned, it is the owner's responsibility to care for the headstone and arrange for any upkeep. You may want to consider taking out insurance to cover the cost of any damage.
Memorial plaques
There are two types of memorial plaque available.
One that can be displayed on the Garden of Remembrance wall and one that can be displayed on a "mushroom" memorial.
Both types of plaque can be leased for a ten-year period, with the option to renew the lease when it ends.
There is no further charge for maintenance or upkeep during the period of the lease. Prices vary depending on the type of plaque you choose.
How to apply for a plaque
To apply for a plaque, complete and return an application form to Knowsley Bereavement Services Office.

title: Public funerals
summary: If someone dies without leaving a will and there is no known next of kin, their property and possessions (their "estate") will pass to the Crown. This is known as bona vacantia.
intro: If someone dies without leaving a will and there is no known next of kin, their property and possessions (their "estate") will pass to the Crown. This is known as bona vacantia.
text:
If we have information about someone who has died in this way, we will inform the Treasury Solicitor's office. They will then publish the person's name, date of death, and area of death on their website.
We receive many Freedom of Information (FOI) requests about bona vacantia cases. To make it easier for you to find this information, we have published a list of all the cases we have referred to the Treasury Solicitor on this page.
The Treasury Solicitor's website shows all the information we are able to disclose about these cases under the FOI Act. Therefore, our response to FOI requests for this information is to refer people to that page.

Exemptions
Under section 31 (1) of the FOI Act, we will not publicly disclose details which could open opportunities for criminal acts to be committed, such as theft and identity fraud.
Public health funerals
Under the Public Health (Control of Disease) Act 1984, when a resident dies in the area outside a hospital and there is no one else willing to pay, we will arrange a public health funeral. We will try to locate surviving relatives or friends of the deceased and, in some cases, pass the responsibility on to them.
What costs the council can reclaim
Under section 46 subsection (1) of the Public Health (Control of Disease) Act 1984, the funeral costs are the first expenses claimed on any estate. We are entitled to collect any money due to or belonging to the deceased and to sell any belongings of the deceased in order to help offset the costs of the funeral and expenses.
If, after we have deducted the funeral and associated costs:
the remaining estate is over £500
there are no other bills outstanding
there is no known next of kin
We will refer the remaining estate to the Treasury Solicitor in accordance with their guidelines for referring bona vacantia estates.
It is at this point that we will make information public on this web page.

title: Ceremony fees
summary: Find out more about the costs of a ceremony service in Knowsley.
intro: Find out more about the costs of a ceremony service in Knowsley.
text:
Reservation fee
A reservation fee of £53 is payable at the time of booking. This fee is non-refundable and does not form part of the ceremony fee. Subsequent changes in date, time or venue will be subject to a further £53 charge.
Garden Gazebo
The Garden Gazebo is available for ceremonies April through to October. The garden is open for photographs during daylight hours only.

title: Births
summary: Find out how to register a birth or change a birth record.
intro: Find out how to register a birth or change a birth record.
text:
Book a naming ceremony
A naming ceremony a non-religious celebration of a child's birth and naming. Find out more about booking your child's ceremony here.
Register a birth
Follow our guide on how to book an appointment to register the birth of your child.

title: Deaths and bereavement
summary: Register a death or stillbirth, correct a mistake on a death certificate and access our bereavement services.
intro: Register a death or stillbirth, correct a mistake on a death certificate and access our bereavement services.
text:
Registering a death
Death and bereavements can be a difficult time, find out more here about the simple steps to register a death and how to use the Tell us once service here.
Registering a stillbirth
Losing a baby is devastating, we understand that this is a very difficult time for you and your family. We will ensure that the process of registering the stillbirth is as easy as possible and you get the right information.
Burials and cremations
If you are organising a burial, or burial following a cremation, there are a number of options available to you. Find out more here.
Bereavement services fees
Find out more about the costs of bereavement service fees in Knowsley here.
Memorials
You may wish to arrange for a memorial headstone or plaque to be placed on the grave of a loved one or family member laid to rest in a Knowsley cemetery.
Public funerals
If someone dies without leaving a will and there is no known next of kin, their property and possessions (their "estate") will pass to the Crown. This is known as bona vacantia.
Cemeteries in Knowsley
Knowsley has two award-winning multi-faith cemeteries and two closed churchyards. You can buy burial plots, cremated remains graves, or memorial options in the Garden of Remembrance. Find out more here.

title: Marriages and civil partnerships
summary: Find out more information about getting married or forming civil partnerships in Knowsley.
intro: Find out more information about getting married or forming civil partnerships in Knowsley.
text:
Giving notice of marriage or civil partnership
If you're looking to get married or join a civil partnership in Knowsley you will need to give notice, find out more about how you can book your appointment and the documentation required here.
Marriage and civil partnership venues
Looking for the perfect venue to host your civil marriage or partnership? Take a look at the venues we have to offer in Knowsley.
Reviewing your vows
If you're looking to review your vows find out more here
Ceremony fees
Find out more about the costs of a ceremony service in Knowsley.
